manufacturerProductDescription.media_text: Who Sparked the Montgomery Bus Boycott?: Rosa Parks Who Was the First Man on the Moon?: Neil Armstrong Who Was the Girl Warrior of France?: Joan of Arc Who Was the Voice of the People?: Cesar Chavez Presenting Who HQ Graphic Novels: an exciting new addition to the Who Was? series! Discover the story behind Rosa Parks and the Montgomery Bus Boycott in this compelling graphic novel -- written by Insha Fitzpatrick and illustrated by #DrawingWhileBlack organizer Abelle Hayford. Discover the story behind Neil Armstrong and the Apollo 11 mission in this immersive graphic novel -- by Montague Twins creative duo Nathan Page and Drew Shannon. Discover the story behind Joan of Arc and her journey to triumph in the Hundred Years' War in this captivating graphic novel -- written by Sarah Winifred Searle and illustrated by award-winning cartoonist Maria Capelle Frantz. Discover the story behind Cesar Chavez and the Delano Grape Strike in this moving graphic novel -- written by award-winning author Terry Blas and illustrated by Ignatz-nominated cartoonist Mar Julia.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 31, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Mostly well-written, illustrations portray Joan angry, modern-day politics inserted
reviews.reviewText: We purchased this graphic novel at my 6yo daughter's school's Book Fair. She loves St. Joan of Arc and was excited to read it. As she was reading it, she kept asking if St. Joan used to yell a lot and mentioned that she yells a lot in this graphic novel. When she finished it, she was not left inspired, but rather was disdainful of the portrayal of St. Joan. Upon reading it, I didn't notice dialogue that would imply yelling, but the illustrations of St. Joan show her, in my opinion, aggressive and angry, which is why, I am guessing, that my daughter did not care for the book. On a separate note, the author decided to push her own political agenda by stating the following, "At the time, acts of heresy included...wearing clothes that didn't match your assigned gender". Please don't push your politics on our kids. Keep it neutral. The author could have left out "assigned" and it would have been much more accurate since the concept of "assigning" is so very modern. At the very end of the graphic novel she also stated, "It is true Jeanne helped end a terrible war. It is also true that she promoted violence against people just for having different religious beliefs." Um, examples please? This statement was in her concluding paragraph. Either back it up or leave it out. Poor writing.
Per i giovani appassionati di storia, questo è un viaggio informativo nel passato con il vantaggio di imparare un po' di inglese.
